channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: Pilot of Missing Jet Expressed Interest in Democracy and Atheism on Social Networks
item.description: Posts on the Facebook and YouTube accounts maintained by Capt. Zaharie Ahmad Shah support descriptions of him by friends as a man without extremist leanings in religion or politics.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: U.S. and Russia Swap Sanctions Tit for Tat Over Crimean Crisis
item.description: Moscow responded to President Obama’s expansion of sanctions against Russian officials by banning nine American leaders from entering the country, including Speaker John A. Boehner.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Newly Detected Objects Draw Searchers for Malaysian Plane
item.description: The Australian prime minister said on Thursday that satellite imagery had detected objects in the southern Indian Ocean that might be connected to the missing Malaysia Airlines jet.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: This handout from the Australian Maritime Safety Authority shows the satellite images of the two objects that officials say could possibly be related to Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

item.title: Ukrainian Tumult Highlights European Union’s Errors
item.description: The situation has only underscored Europe’s divisions and exposed the chasm between the bloc’s high-minded aspirations and the rough reality of geopolitics.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: U.N. Warns of Anti-Muslim Violence in Central African Republic
item.description: Navi Pillay, the human rights chief, also criticized the slow international response to what she said was a humanitarian catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Cut in Energy Subsidies Will Only Add to Iranians’ Economic Pain
item.description: Confronted with a lack of funds, President Hassan Rouhani has little option but to take steps that will increase the pain for the voters who put him into office.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Obama Rules Out Military Force Over Ukraine
item.description: President Obama said that the United States will mobilize diplomatic resources “to punish Russia for its seizure of Crimea.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Russian Forces Release Ukraine Naval Commander, Reports Say
item.description: The detention of the commander reflected the blistering pace of Moscow’s moves to cement Russia’s annexation of Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN, ANDREW E. KRAMER and ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian air defense forces on Wednesday moved their belongings out of dormitories near a blockaded military base in the village of Lubimovka, Crimea.

item.title: Bloomberg Should Have Rethought Articles on China, Chairman Says
item.description: Sales of the company’s financial-data terminals declined sharply in China after its news service published articles on the family wealth of high-ranking politicians in the country.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: Peter T. Grauer, chairman of Bloomberg L.P., said being in China “occupies a lot of our thinking."

item.title: India Ink: Bharatiya Janata Party Announces Second Race For Modi
item.description: The fifth list of candidates for the Indian parliamentary elections has Narendra Modi and a senior leader, Lal Krishna Advani, each running for a seat from the state of Gujarat.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA

item.title: DealBook: In Hong Kong, Placing Their Bets on Bitcoin
item.description: A growing field of technology experts, financial players and entrepreneurs believe that mainland China’s unfavorable regulation of Bitcoin has created an opening for Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Distributing envelopes to promote Bitcoin for the ANX exchange.

item.title: Letter From Europe: When the End of War Is the Beginning of War
item.description: In this century, conflicts that end on ill-defined terms merely store up the tinder of future conflagration.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Michelle Obama Stays Connected On Her Visit To China
item.description: On the first lady’s weeklong trip to China, her first ever, her team is harnessing the power of technology to ensure that every step, every impression, is documented.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: Michelle Obama, with her daughters Sasha, right, and Malia, arrived at Beijing Capital International Airport on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Opponents of China Trade Deal Occupy Taiwan’s Legislature
item.description: Protesters said the trade act would “forfeit Taiwan’s future” and accused President Ma Ying-jeou of forcing through the measure without allowing a review of its details.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Banners criticizing President Ma Ying-jeou went up during the occupation of the legislature, which began Tuesday night.

item.title: Letter From India: India’s New Breed of Politician
item.description: As India heads toward general elections, candidates with no political background will throw down the most serious challenge yet to the establishment.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH
item.media:description: Nandan Nilekani, the co-founder of Infosys, has joined the governing Indian National Congress and is running for office for the first time.

item.title: Militants Storm Afghan Police Compound, Killing at Least 10
item.description: The Taliban, who have pledged to disrupt the upcoming presidential election, claimed credit for the attack in the eastern city of Jalalabad.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: 5 Convicted in Gang-Rape Case That Shocked Mumbai
item.description: The men were found guilty Thursday of assaulting a photojournalist and a call-center operator in an abandoned mill building last August.
item.dc:creator: By MANSI CHOKSI and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: India Ink: A Temporary End to a Tour of the Indian Women’s Movement
item.description: The activists Gloria Steinem and Ruchira Gupta conclude their monthlong journey through India in the southern state of Kerala, where people appear to be in more control of their destiny.
item.dc:creator: By GLORIA STEINEM
item.media:description: Jessica Neuwirth from Donor Direct Action sitting by the backwaters of Kumarakom in the southern Indian state of Kerala.

item.title: German Energy Push Runs Into Problems
item.description: Berlin's ambition to use renewable power sources without harming its industrial might has gained urgency with new uncertainties about Russian gas.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: India Ink: Delhi’s Indo-Western Style
item.description: A young Indian finds fashion inspiration in a national hero in New Delhi’s artsy Hauz Khas Village neighborhood.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: U.N. Delays Action on China’s Rights Report
item.description: A normally routine event at the United Nations — the adoption of a country’s human rights report — has become a showdown over China’s treatment of dissidents.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Newly Detected Objects Draw Searchers for Malaysian Plane
item.description: The Australian prime minister said on Thursday that satellite imagery had detected objects in the southern Indian Ocean that might be connected to the missing Malaysia Airlines jet.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Australian Maritime Safety Authority, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: A handout picture made available on Thursday by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority shows a map of the search area for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: One Year Later, Dead Pigs Discovered in Another Chinese River
item.description: On Wednesday, officials in Nanchang, the capital of Jiangxi Province, said that more than 100 dead pigs had been pulled from the Gan River.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A photograph taken on Tuesday showing a dead pig pulled from the Gan River in Nanchang, Jiangxi Province.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Assault on Hong Kong Media Executives Adds to Press Freedom Concerns
item.description: An attack on two executives of a Hong Kong newspaper by men with iron bars is the second such high-profile assault in less than a month.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A protester held a sign calling for the protection of press freedom during a demonstration in Hong Kong in support of Kevin Lau, the former editor of the Ming Pao newspaper who was stabbed by two knife-wielding assailants.

item.title: Placing Their Bets on Bitcoin
item.description: A growing field of technology experts, financial players and entrepreneurs believe that mainland China’s unfavorable regulation of Bitcoin has put Hong Kong on the edge of something big.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG
